steps.title: Measure the length of brake line needed with measuring tape.
steps.content: Measure the length of brake line needed with measuring tape.

steps.title: Cut brake tubing to the desired length with tubing cutters or a hacksaw.
steps.content: Cut brake tubing to the desired length with tubing cutters or a hacksaw. [1] X Research source Cutters will cut round tubing squarely without causing burrs. You will have to remove burrs if you use a hacksaw.

steps.title: Use a flaring tool or a double flare tool to form the tubing's flare.
steps.content: Use a flaring tool or a double flare tool to form the tubing's flare. [2] X Research source The instructions for both types of single flare tools are given below.

steps.title: Put the cone of the tool over the end of the tubing.
steps.content: Put the cone of the tool over the end of the tubing. Lower the cone down until it is centered over the tube's end.

steps.title: Turn the advance screw to move the cone until the part of the tube being flared is firmly against the countersunk recess of the bar.
steps.content: Turn the advance screw to move the cone until the part of the tube being flared is firmly against the countersunk recess of the bar.

steps.title: Inspect the new flare for cracks, splits, or other imperfections.
steps.content: Inspect the new flare for cracks, splits, or other imperfections. If the line is damaged at all, replace it with a new one.

steps.title: Place the cone over the end of the tubing and move it down until the cone is centered.
steps.content: Place the cone over the end of the tubing and move it down until the cone is centered. On a generating flare tool, the flare is formed in the air instead of in the recessed part of the bar.

steps.title: Turn the advance screw several revolutions.
steps.content: Turn the advance screw several revolutions. Check the manual for the number of revolutions needed for the flare size you need.

steps.title: Check the new flare for any imperfections such as splits.
steps.content: Check the new flare for any imperfections such as splits. If you end up with any damage, even a hairline crack, toss out the brake line and try again with a new one.

steps.title: Clamp your tubing into the flaring bar.
steps.content: Clamp your tubing into the flaring bar. [3] X Research source Ensure the depth is equal to the edge of your tubing size insert.

steps.title: Install the yoke and use it to advance the cone into the tube until a bell shape forms.
steps.content: Install the yoke and use it to advance the cone into the tube until a bell shape forms. [4] X Research source Remove the insert and finish advancing the cone into the bell. The bell shape of the tube forms the double thickness flare.
